citation.article-title: Morphology and molecular evaluation of Iphinoe spelaeobios gen. nov., sp. nov. and Loriellopsis cavernicola gen. nov., sp. nov., two stigonematalean cyanobacteria from Greek and Spanish caves
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Loriellopsis cavernicola Hernández-Mariné and Canals gen. nov., sp. nov.

Loriellopsis cavernicola [Lo.ri.el.lop′sis. N.L. n. Loriella name of a genus; Gr. fem. n. opsis aspect, appearance; N.L. fem. n. Loriellopsis that which appears similar to Loriella; ca.ver.ni′co.la. L. n. caverna a hollow, cavity, cave, cavern, grotto; L. suff. -cola (from L. n. incola) inhabitant, dweller; N.L. cavernicola inhabitant in caves].
Creeps on the substrata, sometimes interwoven with other cyanobacteria.
Trichomes are uniseriate, surrounded by a mucilaginous sheath, embedded with calcareous deposits at the base.
Trichomes are irregularly branched, at the tips (true V-branching) and laterally (true T-branching).
Cells are cylindrical or torulose, 4.5–6.5 µm long and violet.
A ring of mucilaginous material helps separation.
The phylotype strain is LF-B5, isolated from a Spanish cave.
Herbarium of Philadelphia (PH), Academy of Natural Sciences: 1089025.
